Operational costs are the costs associated with the day-to-day activities of an NGO, such as staff salaries, transportation, and supplies. In Africa, these costs can be particularly high due to the lack of infrastructure and the need to import many goods and services. This can limit the amount of aid that an NGO is able to provide to vulnerable communities.

Another challenge that NGOs in Africa often face is the lack of reliable accountability systems. Many NGOs rely on donor funding to support their operations, and donors often require NGOs to demonstrate that they are using funds efficiently and effectively. However, in many cases, NGOs lack the systems and processes to track and report on their activities in a transparent and accountable manner. This can make it difficult for NGOs to demonstrate their impact and can lead to a lack of trust from donors and the communities they serve.
